I had five, and when the little ones started to go to school then I went to look for a job.
And that's where we went me and my friends to go part time while the kids were in school.

No, Gosainan.
Gosainan.

Yeah, cos I was living in Lichau.

And his mother and father was living there.
But before we had that house, we lived with his mother and father before they had the council house.

Well they were in school I know.
Cos I didn't like to leave him on his own too young.

No I can't remember that date.

So it would be about...
In the early 70s then that you went then?
Yes, cos I remembered after, it was 1973 that we were made redundant.
So that's what I remembered when I looked it up, it was 1973.
So your first job then in the factory was in Fisher and Price?
Fisher and Price, yes.
And where was that, where was the factory?
Well next door to Mettoys, so just about next door to Mettoys it was.
That's Forest Park?
Yes, yes, Forest Park.
How did you get to work there then?
By bus.
Sometimes if we might have a lift, but very rare, but we had to go for a bus then.
It was a service bus, not a works bus?
Oh no, a service bus, another works bus then.
So you went, you decided, two or three of you together decided to go?
Well two of us, yes, well three of us, but one didn't stay, she didn't like it, she only stayed one day.
She didn't like it, so my other friend and I stayed then for a while, but she left as well.
I don't think she went to Mettoys, I'm not sure.
The three of you went up together, did you have an interview?
Yes, we had an interview, yes.
So we had that, but it was part time it was, at 9.00 until 3.00, because we can come home for the time the children come home from school, see.
So that was a nice time, but of course when we went over to Mettoys we had to go full time, which was a problem, but we did manage it then.
Well, because the oldest girl, she was there to watch them coming home from school and she was there to like a moment of work, so they were all right.
Otherwise I would have to leave there if it was full time, because I was puzzling to stay really, because I was thinking of the kids there.
But my daughter and my son as well, they said they'd watch them, so that's the day then they went full time then.
So you were working part time, were there lots of others working part time?
Oh yes, a lot of us were part time, yes.
What did Fisher Price actually produce?
Wooden toys, the things like that, you know, well they're still selling them now, and they were good toys, the Fisher Price was, very good toys.
What were you doing there? Do you remember the exact job you were doing?
Well we were on the line, we were, see, and I can remember one thing we were doing, as the people who will remember, you know the dogs that you pull, we were doing them, we were, and I can't remember the other ones, we were doing a lot of them.
So do you remember what you were doing to this dog? Were there different parts?
Oh yes, different parts, everybody was doing their different parts here. I'm not sure what I will remember. I think I was putting the wheels on, I'm not sure.
It's on the line then?
It goes up to the line, see, until they come to the end, and then there's a supervisor then to see that there's no reject, and nothing like that's on it as well.
So did you have any training at all?
No, he didn't have no training.
Just told what to do?
Just told what to do and carry on.
Do you remember your first day there? What sort of impression did that do on you?
We were a bit nervous, because the foreman that we called was there, I can't remember his name. We were all afraid of him.
Because if the machine happened to break, we were afraid to tell him, because he didn't like the machines to be broken, so we were calling the boys then to come and mend it for us.
So that's what we went to do then. He's all right to work with, but don't get the machines broken. He doesn't like that at all.
Is that because he had to produce so much?
That's what I tried, as well, see.
So he produced so much work, time and motion, time and body, is it?
Yes, yes.
Do you remember the first day at all, or you don't remember that?
No, not really.
How many other girls would have been working then on the line in the room, in the factory? Was it very big?
No, the Pritchard Price wasn't that big, not as big as Mettoy's. It was very small. Well, not small, and it wasn't big. But Mettoy's was the biggest, well, it was.
How many women have been working on the line? Can you give us some idea?
10 or 20?
No, it won't be 10 or 20. It could be 10, but it won't be 20. Say about 10. 10 of us would be less, might.
Did you have to wear anything special to that?
No, no, I didn't have to wear anything special. Just ordinary clothes.
Did you wear overall at all?
Not unless you put your own on, like, if you had your own, yes. But otherwise, no.
So did they make that whole dog, or all the toy in the factory from beginning to end?
Oh, yes, from the beginning to the line up to the end, then, see. But they would do it as well, but I can't remember what others were doing.
So they must have got the parts themselves?
Oh, yes, they got the parts, and then we got to send them them, so.
They didn't make the parts in the factory?
No, no, we just got to put them together, like, see.

Oh, yes, a packing there as well, at the end as well, see, after the supervisor or the one that's got that seat, or that is in good order, you know what I mean.
It's in good nick, then. There's nothing wrong with it, and then the packers, the packing map, then, see.
Right, because today, toys have to pass, you know, standard, don't they?
Yeah, yeah.
Was that the case then?
Oh, yes, they had to do that as well, yeah. They had to do that as well.

Oh, yes, yes. Oh, yes.
And so some of them?
Because any rejects, then, they put it in another box, then.
Do you remember how much you were earning at all?
No, I can't remember how much I was earning. No, it was very small.
So why did you decide to go into a factory rather than to a shop to work at that time?
I don't know, we just suggested to go to a shop, that's what they wanted to come, because I thought you would be no good in the shop.
There was lots of factories at that time, wasn't there?
Yes, it was a lot of factories. Well, yes, it was a loads down in, what was it, there was a sewing factory down there as well, and, oh, there was a few factories down there, really.
So you could have had a choice?
Oh, yes, I could have had a choice, yes, there was loads down there.
And what was the attitude towards, you know, women who worked in factories, were they all right to you?
Oh, yes, they were good, yes, we all enjoyed ourselves there and had fun as well. Well, we had a lot of fun there, it was.
When you were working then on the, when you had your wages, what did you spend your wages on? Was that something extra in the house, or was it the main?
Well, it was a bit extra to, well, towards, because my husband wasn't working then.
Ah, right.
He wasn't working then.
So it was less, yes.
So it was less, yes.
Yes, because it was less towards the children and food as well, see, because, I mean, it wasn't much, but it was something.
Otherwise, if he was working, I'd had good wages, I wouldn't have bothered to go to work, but he wasn't working at the time then.
What was your husband's job?
Well, before he went bad, he was on the Ashman in the council, driving the Ash lorries, he was then.
And then he went to the steelworks in Pond de Dyles, Morgan and Rees, and then for a while, when he got better, yes.
So when he was ill, you know, that's when you went to work?
He went to work, yes, yes, that's when I went to work then.
So it was important then?
Oh yes, it was important, because you had five children then to bring up, then see.
So that's why I went out to work.
So when you were working, did you join the union at all?
Yes, we did join the union, yes, we did join, we had to join it then in those days in the factories, yes, we did join then.
Was there some part of the wage that was taken out for the union membership?
Oh yes, we were taking some of that out as well, and the stamps as well, but only half a stamp we were paying, because it was only part time.
We could have paid the full, but because we weren't earning that much, we went off of it then, so it was half a stamp we were paying then at that time.
Did you have to clock in?
Oh yes, we had to clock in, yes.
And clock out?
And clock out, yes.
So when you clocked out, did you stop working straight away, or did you finish a job when you were?
Oh no, well we had to finish a job first, and we had to get them out, they gave us a target to get out, and we had to do that target, otherwise you wouldn't have your bonus sort of thing, you know.
So we had to do that before we could clock out anyhow, but we did manage it anyhow.
So it was so much a day exactly?
Oh yes, we had to get our target out, they'd tell us how many we were supposed to get out, we got to try and get that out.
Did you remember how much that was?
No, I couldn't.
No.
And then the bonus was on top of your wage, was it?
Yes, if we had the bonus we'd go on top of our wage then, see, to build it up a bit then, yes.
And when were you paid?
On a Friday, we paid da da da.
In cash?
Oh yes, yes, we were preferred in cash.
And do you ever go to the office, or how were you paid?
No, they bring it out, they bring it around.
I don't know if the supervisors, they bring them around for you, in their packets ready for you.
Were you given pay rises, you know? Do you remember if the money went up at all?
No, I don't think, it was only that the bonus was making it more in the way.
If you can get the bonus out.
How many years did you work in Fisher Price before moving to Metoey?
I don't know.
Were you talking about four, five, six years or more?
No, it couldn't have been that. Say three years.

No, I don't think we ever bothered with holidays.

So we were.
Right. Did you enjoy working there?

Oh yes, women mostly, yes.

It was a little bit, not much, mind you, it was, because there's machines there as well, like see.
So it was a bit, but not so much as all that.

No, no, they didn't know I could sing.

Yeah, there was music on, but it was very cold there.
It was cold in the winter there, but they did bring the machines out.
I didn't know this gas, but it was very sickly and it was horrible.
That's the only thing we could have is to keep us warm.
And of course the summer then, they did bring us drinks around for us because it was so warm there.
We had a nice summer then.
And we were having free drinks then to cool us down a bit.
So what drinks were they then? Squash.
Squash, yeah, squash, let's see.
So why was it hot then there?
Well, it was glass up top as well, see.
So the bed was cold and the bed was hot.

No, I don't think so. No, I can't remember coming out and strike there.

You were talking about your mother and the tinworks.
Oh yeah, the tinworks.
Was there any?
Well, perhaps there could be.

No, that's the word, no.

So anybody was taken ill.

Trina, you're going half past nine.

But not in Fisher Price?
No.

Oh yes.

And some of the women were doing it as well.
Right.
Yes, in the paint shop there.
